secText: Vocab ulary: Big Bang, black holes, dark energy, dark matter, gravitational lensing, Higgs boson, length contraction, particle accelerator, reference frame, speed of light in a vacuum, Standard Model, time dilation

STEM Skills:
1. Review reference frame.
2. Review the speed of light.
3. Review gravitational force.
4. Review density.
5. Review the Standard Model.

Language Arts Connection: Encourage students to continue recording their thoughts, questions, and vocabulary definitions and sentences in their Science Notebooks. For an explanation of how to incorporate Science Notebooks into your instruction, see Chapter 1 Overview, Part 1.

Writing a Research Report Instruct students to write a five- to seven-page research report. Topics might come from their Science Notebook, content from this chapter, or from a list that you provide. You might also brainstorm a list as a class activity. The purpose of the paper is for the students to become an “expert” on a topic. Their audience is the scientific community.

Explain to students they will write either an Argumentative Paper or an Analytical Paper. If they choose to write an argumentative paper, they must be prepared to persuade the audience that their opinion is supported by evidence.  For an analytical paper, students should pose a question that they then explore and evaluate.
Once students have an approved topic, ask them to create an outline for your review. Next they should write a first draft. You may wish to have them work in groups to revise this first draft.
Remind students to cite their sources.
